Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Title: COMMITTEES
text: On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties I present the committee's report entitled Report 65: Treaties tabled 7 December 2004 and 8 February 2005, together with the minutes of proceedings and transcripts of evidence received by the committee. Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper.

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Title: COMMITTEES
text: This report deals with the Agreement on Bilateral Cooperation between the Government of Australia and the Government of the Kingdom of Thailand; the termination of the Agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of the Slovak Republic on Trade and Economic Cooperation; the Joint Agreement on Enhanced Cooperation between Australia and Papua New Guinea; the Convention for the Unification of Certain Rules for Internamendations tional Carriage by Air; amendments to the schedule to the International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling, 1946; the Agreement on Social Security between the Government of Australia and the Government of Malta; the Beijing amendment to the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer; and amendments, agreed at Bangkok in October 2004, to appendixes I and II of the Convention on Intertem. national Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora. Report 65 contains the findings and recommendations of the review conducted by the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties into eight treaty actions tabled in the parliament on 7 December 2004 and 8 February 2005. The treaty actions relate to the matters identified in the full title of the report. I will comment on a selection of the treaty actions considered. Firstly, the committee reviewed the enhanced cooperation agreement with Papua New Guinea. The committee supported the agreement, which would have enabled the deployment of Australian police and other on officials to deliver assistance to Papua New Guinea. The committee acknowledged the urgent need for the agreement to be in force prior to the treaty action being tabled in parliament and so supported the national interest exemption being invoked. The committee awaits the outcome of developments, following the decision of the Supreme Court of Papua New Guinea that Australian police and personnel withdraw, and the possible renegotiation of the terms of the agreement. The committee has found that there have been a number of treaties relating to the stability of Pacific island countries which have invoked the national interest exemption and entered into force before being tabled in parliament. This report contains some recomwhereby the committee has recommended that in cases such as these it receives an urgent briefing on the proposed treaty action. Secondly, the Convention for the Unification of Certain Rules for International Carriage by Air updates, and will eventually replace, the current convention and also a number of subsequent conventions and protocols which together form the Warsaw sysThe Montreal convention will provide a uniform code that modernises the international air carrier liability framework and will provide measures such as electronic documentation to assist the movement of air passengers, baggage and cargo. Thirdly, the amendments to the Schedule to the International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling concern a multilateral treaty that regulates the conservation and use of whale stocks. The initial focus of the convention was to ensure international control of postwar development of the commercial whaling industry. More recently, the International Whaling Commission, established under the convention, has been a vehicle for conservation measures such as the 1982 decision to implement a moratorium on commercial whaling. The committee found that Australia already prohibits killing, injuring or interfering with whales in Australian waters and that, under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act, Australia provides a higher level of protection for whales than provided for under the convention. Lastly, the amendments to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora concern a multilateral treaty which regulates international trade in specimens of wild fauna and flora. This treaty action recognises that international cooperation will protect and conserve endangered and threatened species of fauna and flora from exploitation through international trade. This treaty provides for differing degrees of regulation of trade, resulting in differing levels of protection for each species. In conclusion, it is the view of the committee that it is in Australia's interest treaties considered in Report 65 to be ratified. The committee has made its recommendations accordingly. I commend the report to the House.

Speaker: Mr WILKIE
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I rise to speak in support of Report 65 and the recommendations made by the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties. I support the remarks of the chair, the member for Boothby, and particularly welcome the recommendations supporting ratification of the Convention for the Unification of Certain Rules for International Carriage by Air. I want to make some remarks about some of the other treaties mentioned. The review made a number of findings in relation to the benefits for Australia of entering into specific treaties and the issue surrounding each treaty action. The committee supports binding treaty action for the eight treaty actions reviewed. The majority of the proposed treaty actions serve to strengthen political, diplomatic, security and social ties between Australia and treaty parties, as indicated in individual treaty chapters in the report. There are, however, instances where the committee process is negated for national security or interest reasons. A recurring issue of reviews is the impact on the process of review by proposed treaties when the national interest exemption is invoked by the government. An example where the national interest exemption was used is the Enhanced Cooperation Agreement with Papua New Guinea. The agreement enabled the deployment of Australian police and other officials to deliver assistance to Papua New Guinea. Subsequently the Supreme Court of Papua New Guinea ruled that the agreement was in breach of the Papua New Guinea constitution and subsequently Australian police and other officials were withdrawn from Papua New Guinea. Regardless of the outcome in this case, the committee for the acknowledged the urgent need for the agreement to be in force prior to the treaty action being tabled in parliament and parliamentary consideration of the agreement. However, this outcome highlights the view that it would be beneficial to the committee, and indeed to the Australian parliament, if in these circumstances an urgent briefing could be provided on such agreements by the minister. The committee has recommended accordingly. The committee also looked at a number of other treaties which I will speak about. The Agreement on Bilateral Cooperation between the Government of Australia and the Government of the Kingdom of Thailand will strengthen political, diplomatic, security and social ties between Australia and Thailand through cooperation and information exchange. The agreement also establishes a Joint Commission on Bilateral Cooperation, which will meet biannually at the ministerial level to review progress on cooperative activities identified in the agreement. The commission would also continue to strengthen ties between Australia and Thailand by identifying further areas for potential cooperation. The committee supports the Termination of the Agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of the Slovak Republic on Trade and Economic Cooperation. Accession to the EU requires a country to terminate existing bilateral agreements. This treaty action will allow the Slovak Republic to accede to the European Union. The committee also supports the Agreement on Social Security between the Government of Australia and the Government of Malta. The agreement is part of a network of existing social security bilateral agreements and is similar to others that we have with other countries. It will provide access to certain Australian and Maltese social security benefits and limited portability of these benefits between the countries. The Beijing Amendment to the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer recognises the environmental and human health problems resulting from the damage to the ozone layer. The amendment aims to diminish this damage by committing parties to a reduction of the consumption of substances that harm that ozone layer. I would like to express my appreciation and gratitude to the committee secretariat, who put in untiring efforts to help get these matters dealt with and brought before the parliament. They make a fantastic contribution, and it should be recognised.

Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Title: COMMITTEES
text: Fraser) (12.41 pm)On behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Account I present the committee's report on the annual reports of the National Native Title Tribunal, the Indigenous Land Corporation and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Account 2003-2004, together with evidence received by the committee. Ordered that the report be made a parliamentary paper.

Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Title: COMMITTEES
text: On behalf of the committee, I wish to say a few things. Often when we have reviews in the parliament of annual reports of agencies, I have not been convinced that it has been a productive process-and many committees have chosen not to give it a high priority-but in this instance I regard it very highly. It is a very important iterative process where the parliament learns of developments in an area of major social reform with regard to native title and where the agencies involved are kept accountable as the new issues evolve. I welcome the fact that the Chairman of the Native Title Tribunal, Mr Neate, in his evidence to the committee, said how much the tribunal has valued the work of the committee in previous years in reviewing and making suggestions about reporting and other issues. This is an important year because the 10th anniversary of the commencement of the Native Title Act and the establishment of the tribunal occurred midway through the year under review. We see here evidence of a major social reform settling down and being embedded in the operations of society and the economy. We see evidence from the tribunal of Indigenous land use agreements being negotiated and registered in a steadily increasing number and that future act consent determinations are becoming an increasingly common means of finalising negotiations. There has been political controversy around issues to do with native title, and it not appropriate for me to speak on behalf of others about that, but irrespective of that we have had a major change in the Australian economic and social fabric as a result of native title and it is now settling down and working in ways that many people hoped it would. There emerged in evidence a reiteration of the importance of the provisions in the Native Title Act that refer to negotiation in faith, which arises in the case of future act negotiations. I think the parliament, in appreciating that this is an important element of the Native Title Act, should in other legislation similarly look at the question of requiring parties to negotiate in good faith. Those are the principal comments I want to make of substance. I do hope that some of the guidelines for which we are waiting from the Commonwealth government with regard to native title matters will be forthcoming in this 12-month period when we review it again. If they are not, I will have something to say at the tabling of that report, but I do not wish to enter into that controversy now. The committee has in its conclusion commended the Native Title Tribunal on its comprehensive and accessible annual report and made some suggestions for inclusion in future. We have had, in dealings with issues to do with the Indigenous Land Corporation, an analysis of the impact of changes in ATSIC. The committee raised the issue of the effect on the corporation of the abolition of ATSIC and regional councils, and the ILC voiced some concern about the loss of the regional councils and ATSIC as resources for advice and consultation. We will need to turn to the next annual report to see how this issue is evolving, how that major change is being dealt with by the ILC and how the ILC has been able to perform. There has been concern from the committee in the past about aspects of the reports of is the ILC and the related reports of what was called the land fund and what is now called the land account, but the general view is that the corporation has taken note of comments from previous reports and acted on them and we welcome that change. I commend the report to the House and I thank the other members and the staff of the committee for facilitating these important hearings.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: DELEGATION REPORTS
text: I present the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the 13th annual meeting of the Asia Pacific Parliamentary Forum held in Ha Long City, Vietnam, from 10 to 13 January 2005. This delegation included the member for Cowan as deputy leader, the members for Capricornia and Hume, Senator Eggleston and me as leader. The Asia Pacific Parliamentary Forum is an organisation with great significance for Australia because it is an assembly of members of national parliaments in the Asia-Pacific region. Since 1993 it has met each January to discuss matters of mutual concern-mainly strategic, economic, social and cultural issues. These meetings provide a valuable opportunity for Australian members of parliament to hold discussions with parliamentarians from the region on matters of common interest. The focus of the Asia Pacific Parliamentary Forum is on countries that are Australia's neighbours and that are therefore of immediate concern to our regional strategic and economic interests. Giving strength to this focus are the formal objectives of the forum. These are, firstly, to deepen our understanding of the interests and policy concerns of countries in the region; secondly, to examine the major political, social and cultural developments arising from economic growth and integration; thirdly, to promote cooperation; and, fourthly, to foster the roles we have as national parliamentarians to build up a sense of regional cohesion and cooperation. None of us will forget the impact of the tragic earthquake and tsunami on this meeting that was held only two weeks after the event. While it cast a shadow over the meeting and we were deeply conscious of the suffering and loss amongst our colleagues from other parliaments, we were also glad of the opportunity to express our sympathy and friendship to these colleagues. They were keen to inform us of the impact of the disaster on their own countries, but they were equally keen to acknowledge the great assistance they were receiving and the spirit of friendship and cooperation which was behind the generous and immediate response to the disaster. On behalf of the parliament, I expressed to the meeting our sympathy to all those affected, particularly those who suffered so much in Indonesia, Thailand and Malaysia. The tsunami demonstrated to all of us how a single event can affect many countries-and that among the diverse countries of our region there is cohesion and strong bonds of friendship based on shared humanity, compassion and common interest. I was also able to reiterate Australia's strong and continuing support for the aims and objectives of the forum and our commitment to helping to achieve a regional and international environment that is peaceful and secure. I will turn now to the substantive subject matter of the meeting. As is customary at these meetings, sessions were broken into three main areas: political and security issues, economic and trade issues and cooperation in addressing regional issues of general interest. I spoke to the session on the regional and international political and security situation and, in doing so, I emphasised that, as globalisation increases economic interdependence, this in turn increases countries' shared stakes in stability and security. The roles of the ASEAN Regional Forum and APEC in countering threats to stability and security were emphasised, together with Australia's support for capacity building in regional states. The report discusses other resolutions proposed by Australia and the delegation's contributions to debate and negotiation. The issues addressed included international terrorism, landmines, the world and regional economic situation and the environment. As well as debate in the plenary, the delegation took an active role in all meetings of the drafting committee. In addition, the delegation participated in a number of successful bilateral meetings with other delegations, including the President of the National Assembly of Vietnam, the Speaker of the Indonesian House of Representatives and the leader of the delegation from the People's Republic of China. On behalf of the delegation I would like express our thanks to the Australian Ambassador to Vietnam, Mr Joe Thwaites, Ms Sandra Henderson from the embassy in Hanoi and staff from the National Assembly of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam. I also thank the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Parliamentary Library and the Parliamentary Relations Office. I wish to place on cord my sincere thanks to my former senior adviser, Peter Gibson, whose depth of understanding of the APPF and analytical and organisational skills provided a very high level of support to our delegation. In conclusion, would like to thank all members of the delegation for their active support and involvement and also Catherine Cornish, the hard working secretary to the delegation.

Speaker: Ms LIVERMORE
Title: DELEGATION REPORTS
text: As you mentioned, Mr Speaker, the deputy leader of the delegation to Vietnam earlier this year was the member for Cowan. He has been held up this morning, so I am very pleased to have the opportunity to step in and speak to this report of our participation in the meeting of the Asia Pacific Parliamentary Forum in Vietnam in January. As you noted, Mr Speaker, the APPF has great significance for the parliament and for Australia because it is an assembly of members of national parliaments in our own region, Asia-Pacific. In preparing for and attending this meeting, the delegation was conscious of the strong contributions of previous delegations from this parliament and we were determined to continue this tradition. As you mentioned, Mr Speaker, at the time of the meeting we were all still greatly shocked by the impact of the Indian Ocean tsunami of 26 December 2004. There was unanimous support for commemoration and discussion of the tsunami before any other business was considered. Before the meeting began to discuss the tsunami, we were shown a very powerful video by the delegation from to Indonesia. This had graphic footage of the arrival and aftermath of the tsunami. Coming into that meeting we thought we had seen all the horrors that we could possibly see on our own television coverage, but this video brought it home very graphically. The long silence that followed the end of the broadcast indicated the emotional effect re- on all of us at the meeting. Members of all delegations were pleased to have the opportunity to show our sympathy and support for those who were affected so deeply by the disaster. Our own delegation was pleased, I Mr Speaker, that you were able to outline to the meeting the high level of assistance and sympathy provided by the Australian people, government and opposition. Delegates from the countries affected by the disaster were very quick to express their gratitude for the support and friendship that had already been demonstrated by neighbours in the region, including Australia. There was useful discussion about the long-term technical and financial support that will be needed, especially the need for an early warning system in the region and elsewhere in the world, and I am pleased that practical steps are being taken in this direction. The meeting discussed a range of subject matters that are relevant to our region. Broadly, these covered political and security issues, economic and trade issues and cooperation to address regional issues of common interest. Mr Speaker, you have referred already to the particular aspects that were ered by our resolutions and debate, and the report discusses them in chapter 2. For my own part I want to mention briefly the debate on the subject of the environment. I took the lead on our motion on the environment, and the particular emphasis of that motion was on the Barbados program of action for the sustainable development of small island developing states. Around the same time as the APPF meeting in Vietnam in January there was a meeting in Mauritius to review the implementation of the Barbados program of action. The motion that I put to the meeting spelled out the challenges facing small island developing states and called on all parliaments to examine the outcomes from the Mauritius meeting and to redouble their efforts to assist our small island neighbours with the challenges they are facing. I am pleased to say that motion was supported by a number of other countries and was eventually passed as a resolution by the meeting. Other issues with a particular regional focus were discussed at the meeting's session on cooperation in addressing common issues in the Asia-Pacific region. These issues included infectious diseases such as bird flu, resources for sustainable development and the role of cultural exchange in promoting dialogue and understanding among nations. The broad nature of this discussion was valuable because it enabled all delegations to raise issues of current concern and interest. All of us in the Australian delegation participated in the work of the plenary as well the informal meetings that followed debate of the motions that were proposed. These informal meetings were interesting opportunities to gain an understanding of the perspective of our colleagues from other countries and to offer them a deeper understanding of our Australian perspective. Negotiacov- tions were sometimes a bit robust but they were conducted and completed with goodwill. I too would like to thank the Australian Embassy staff in Vietnam, including Mr Joe Thwaites and Ms Sandra Henderson. Ms Henderson's cheerful and sustained efforts were appreciated by all of us. The organising committee and staff from the National Assembly of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam made every effort to ensure that the meeting was successful. The National Assembly appointed Ms Tu Anh to provide direct liaison support between the meeting's secretariat and our delegation. The people of Ha Long City gave all of us a warm welcome and we noticed that the friendliness extended beyond the public, formal occasions and continued throughout our entire time there. I also want to acknowledge and thank the staff of the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Parliamentary Relations Office who gave us great assistance. (Time expired) 112th Inter-Parliamentary Union Assembly, Manila and a bilateral visit to the Solomon Islands

Speaker: Mrs HULL
Title: DELEGATION REPORTS
text: I present the report of the Australian Delegation to the 112th Inter-Parliamentary Union Assembly held in Manila and a bilateral visit to the Solomon Islands. I had the very real privilege of leading this delegation and I am pleased to report to the House that it was a hard working, cohesive and effective delegation. I place on record my thanks to the depas uty leader of the delegation, the member for Fowler, who is currently in the House, the member for Mackellar and certainly the member for Fraser. I also thank Senator Grant Chapman and Senator Julian MCGauran. All of these people made significant contributions to our work and were a delight to travel with in Manila and the Solomon Islands. I understand the member for Fowler will address that part of the report dealing with the bilateral visit to the Solomon Islands. In addition I would like to thank Mr Neil Bessell and Dr Barbara Cooper for their assistance, which went above and beyond the call of duty at all times in their endeavours service each and every one of the delegation. We place on record our very sincere thanks to both Mr Bessell and Dr Cooper. I commend to honourable members the summary of our work that appears at page 3 of the report. It shows that members of this delegation made a real contribution to the IPU's work in Manila. I think this contribution was all the more significant this time given that for four of us this was our first IPU assembly and a learning curve indeed. I am sure previous delegates will agree that the structure, statutes, rules, practices and procedures of the IPU take some time to absorb and understand. We were absolutely dedicated and 100 per cent in attendance. This delegation took a strategic approach to its work. We agreed on tasks and responsibilities long before going to Manila, and held daily meetings during the assembly to assess situations and determine positions. This enabled delegates to participate fully in agenda items and meetings during the entire assembly. For example, the assembly has a general debate on the political, economic and social situation in the world under the overall theme of the impact of domestic and international policies on the situation of women. The rules also allowed this debate to include matters relevant to the emergency agenda item, and the member for Mackellar made a wonderful contribution including important comments on Australia's response to the Boxing Day 2004 tsunami. The delegation was particularly pleased to get Mrs Bishop elected to the committee that drafted the final resolution on the emergency agenda item on natural disasters and the role of parliaments in prevention, rehabilitation, reconstruction and the protection of vulnerable groups. The IPU has standing committees like our committee structure and considers issues and formulates recommendations or resolutions. to Mrs Irwin, the member for Fowler, addressed the First Committee on Peace and International Security on the role of parliaments in the establishment and functioning of mechanisms to provide for the judgment and sentencing of war crimes, crimes against humanity, genocide and terrorism, with a view to avoiding impunity-and a very good address it was. Senator MCGauran also addressed the first committee with an enormously informative address. The member for Fraser addressed the Second Committee on Sustainable Development, Finance and Trade on the role of parliaments in establishing innovative international financing and trading mechanisms to address the problem of debt and achieve the Millennium Development Goals. Following this contribution Mr MCMullan was invited to participate in the UN-IPU panel on financing for development in New York earlier this month. I addressed the Third Committee on Democracy and Human Rights on the very important issue of the role of parliaments in advocating and enforcing observance of human rights in the strategies for the prevention, management and treatment of the HIVAIDS pandemic. I was also honoured to be elected to the Coordinating Committee of Women Parliamentarians. This is a short summary of what turned out to be a hectic, exciting and rewarding first IPU Assembly. The delegation performed admirably and with great respect to the Australian parliament. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mrs IRWIN
Title: DELEGATION REPORTS
text: Firstly, I wish to congratulate the member for Riverina in her outstanding role as leader of the delegation. The second part of the IPU delegation report deals with the bilateral visit the Solomon Islands. Ethnic tensions resulting in armed action have disrupted the local economy and functions of government in the Solomons. The aim of the visit therefore included a review of progress made by the Regional Assistance Mission to Solomon Islands, RAMSI, and a gauge of the local response to the work of RAMSI. The delegation visited the RAMSI base in Honiara and was briefed on the progress of operations by the Special Coordinator, Mr James Bately, and other RAMSI officials, including Ms Sandi Peisley, the commander of the participating police force. At a meeting with the Solomons Minister for Police and National Security, the delegation was advised that he regarded the RAMSI operation as a partnership which has had a significant impact on the restoration of law and order on the Solomon Islands. The minister estimated that crime has been reduced by 70 per cent since RAMSI commenced operations. However, at a round-table meeting with 12 members of the Solomons parliament some reservations about the role of RAMSI were raised. While it was felt that RAMSI was appreciated, it needs to be tidied up. MPs expressed the view that RAMSI was supposed to be a partnership but the sovereignty of the Solomon Islands needed to be respected and the government needed to take a leading role in how RAMSI was operating. This was completely different from the view given at our meeting with the Prime Minister, the Hon. Sir Alan Kemakeza, who advised that RAMSI was going very well. In his view, RAMSI was not undermining the sovereignty of Solomon Islands. The delegation discussed the Pacific Plan with the foreign minister and government leaders. The plan was described as ambitious and effective, offering security, good governance, growth and sustainable development for the region. The planning minister exto pressed the need to restore social services to rural areas along with infrastructure and assistance to encourage business development. RAMSI was also praised by the finance minister for, in his words, replacing chaos, vandalism and daylight robbery with law and order. He described RAMSI as a guiding light, a saviour and divine intervention. He also pointed to the need for regulation to ensure proper reafforestation, adding that it is possible to have a sustainable industry as long as you replant. This view was confirmed when the delegation visited the island of Kolombangara and inspected timber plantations operated by a private company. At a briefing in Gizo, Mr Dan Raymond, the team leader of an AusAID forestry project, gave a presentation on the need for sustainable forest planning and gave examples of local projects where landowners were assisted and encouraged to plant high-value timber on their land. The delegation also met with opposition MPs and held discussions on aspects of parliamentary ethics and electoral reform. In addition, the delegation met with Ms Sue Ingram, the team leader of the Machinery of Government Program, the Chief Justice, Sir Albert Palmer, and the Speaker of the Solomon Islands parliament, Sir Peter Kenilorea. We also met with women's groups, local government representatives and a range of international aid staff. The highlight of the visit was a 40-kilometre trip in an open boat from New Georgia to Gizo. NA (EMPLOYEE ENTITLEMENTS GUARANTEE) BILL 2005 First Reading Bill presented by Mr Bowen.

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Title: EMPLOYEE PROTECTION
text: Prospect) (1.06 pm)People who lose their jobs when the company they work for goes out of business need all the help they can get. Often these people are older members of the work force and find it difficult to gain new employment. Often they have families and need a flow of income to keep food on the table. The Employee Protection (Employee Entitlements Guarantee) Bill 2005 does not provide these people with handouts. It does not provide them with welfare. It simply gives them a guarantee of access to what is theirs. It antees them access to the leave and redundancy payouts that have accrued to them over the years. Redundancy provisions are, of course, designed for this very eventuality. They are designed to provide sustenance for people who find themselves in difficult circumstances through no fault of their own. What could be so objectionable about a private member's bill which guarantees workers access to the entitlements they have already accrued and which are rightfully theirs? This bill is very similar to those introduced by my predecessor as the member for Prospect, the Hon. Janice Crosio, on an almost annual basis. I pay tribute to Janice's efforts to place and keep this issue on the national agenda and I am proud to be continuing the tradition of the member for Prospect standing up for the rights of workers who have been made redundant. The Employee Protection (Employee Entitlements Guarantee) Bill 2005 provides for the establishment and administration of a scheme to guarantee the payment of wages and other accrued liabilities owed to employees in the event of employer insolvency and for related purposes. The current scheme, put in place by this government, simply does not work. Frankly, the government was dragged kicking and screaming to introduce a scheme to protect employee entitlements. It was against the ideological grain of the government to do so, but it was shamed into action by the collapse of National Textiles. Documents released under the freedom of information laws last year show what a failure the current scheme is. One in five claimants under the GEER scheme is owed an average of $9,000 in outstanding entitlements. Thirty-eight per cent of claimants have to wait for more than 16 weeks to access their guarentitlements; some claimants have been made to wait for more than a year. When the scheme was set up, the then Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, the Hon. Tony Abbott, promised that over 90 per cent of employees would receive 100 per cent of their entitlements. The reality falls far short of this. Perhaps it was a rock solid, rolled gold commitment! This bill involves employers, other than in small business, taking out insurance to ensure that employee entitlements are provided for in the event of the business going into receivership. Employees not only need to be sure that they will receive their entitlements, they also deserve the peace of mind to know that those entitlements are protected in the difficult circumstances when a business is going through tough times. The Prime Minister in the last few days has shown an ability to recognise his government's failings and to take some small steps to remedy those failings. I call on the Prime Minister, other isters and the government to recognise this government's failings in relation to employee entitlements. The scheme proposed in this bill would remedy the shortfalls inherent in the government's scheme. I commend the bill to the House and I call on the government to allow it to be debated. Bill read a first time.

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: PARLIAMENTARY PRIVILEGES
text: The Parliamentary Privileges Act was passed in 1987. It represented a turning point in the history of the Australian parliament, because for the first time the parliament codified much of the law relating to parliamentary privilege. Its decision to do so followed a comprehensive joint select committee's review of the law relating to privilege and contempt tabled in 1984. Most features of the 1987 act were admirable. It established statutory provisions for the protection of witnesses who gave evidence to parliamentary committees. Doubts about the powers of the houses of parliament to impose fines were removed. A threshold definition of contempt was established to help winnow out some of the more trifling matters which had concerned the houses over the years. A limited right of review was established where a house had committed a person to prison for contempt. But the act was deficient in one important respect: section 16(3) provides that witnesses in courts or other tribunals cannot be questioned or examined about evidence they may have given to a house or a committee. That min- has the effect of preventing the cross examination of witnesses as to prior inconsistent statements given to a house or a committee. This provision carries the reach of parliamentary privilege too far. None of us doubts that senators, members and others who take part in parliamentary proceedings, such as committee hearings, should be protected. No-one should be exposed to being sued or prosecuted on account of what they say to a parliamentary committee. I also accept that reasonable people can hold differing views as to whether a person who is on trial for an offence should be able to be cross-examined about prior inconsistent statements they have made to a committee. The Parliamentary Privileges Amendment Bill 2005 I have introduced does not permit that. But it does recognise that the 1987 act goes too far in preventing others from being cross-examined about statements made to a committee, and this amendment bill seeks to alter that position. Mr Spender QC, then shadow Attorney General, speaking in the House of Representatives debate on 5 May 1987 on the bill which was passed and enacted as the Parliamentary Privileges Act I have referred to, put the case for change very well. He said: Let us take a hypothetical case in which a witness comes before a parliamentary committee and gives evidence which is quite untruthful and which amounts to a charge of serious criminal conduct against a third person. That third person is charged. The same witness is called and gives different evidence but the evidence is vital to case for example, vital to the prosecution. Should it not be open to the accused person to say: ‘The evidence he is giving is quite untruthful. What he says now is different from what he said before the parliamentary committee'? Regrettably, preventing such a step would be the effect of the existing legislation. Other honourable members and senators had similar reservations to Mr Spender's on this point but they chose not to delay the passage of the bill with its other many worthwhile reforms. Section 16(3) of the Parliamentary Privileges Act on this point therefore carries parliamentary privilege further than is necessary or desirable. It has the potential to prevent the giving of evidence that, in some future case, may be vital to the rights of an innocent person on trial or to a just outcome in civil litigation. I would like to recognise the scholarship of Sir Clarrie Harders, who devoted a good deal of time to researching this matter and whose comprehensive paper titled Parliamentary privilege-Parliament versus the courts: Cross-examination of committee witnesses, published by the Information and Research Services of the Parliamentary Library over a decade ago, in October 1991, first prompted me to take up the issue as long ago as 1992. The proposition advanced by Sir Clarrie, and incorporated in my bill, is consistent with the laws we have inherited, but it adjusts them to ensure that the perceived needs of the parliament are not allowed to ride roughshod over other considerations, such as the administration of justice. I ask honourable members to take the opportunity to study this measure and I will welcome their comments on it. It comes without any partisanship and I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill. I would hope that the occasion might occur when the Attorney-General and shadow Attorneythe General both support this legislation and that we see its passage in due course. I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill. Bill read a first time.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: AVOIDING DANGEROUS CLIMATE
text: Grayndler) (1.16 pm)I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The Avoiding Dangerous Climate Change (Kyoto Protocol Ratification) Bill 2005 should be passed by this parliament and it should be passed today. It should be passed right now because climate change is happening right now. We are at one of the most important crossroads in our history. Climate change is the greatest threat to the health of Australia and our planet. It is the greatest environmental challenge facing the global community. This bill provides for action by the Australian government. If passed, it will see an end to Australia's complacency and isolation from the global effort to avoid dangerous climate change and will require the Australian government to take action. Firstly, it require the government to ratify the Kyoto protocol within 60 days of the commencement of the act. Secondly, it will require to government to ensure Australia meets its greenhouse emission target set out in the protocol-this is 108 per cent of 1990 levels. Only Iceland has a higher target. Thirdly, the minister must develop a national climate change action plan setting out our national strategy for meeting our greenhouse emission target. Fourthly, the minister would have to establish an annual greenhouse gas inventory and publish the results. And, fifthly, the minister must also develop a framework for involvement in the international trading of carbon. This would include emissions trading but also clean development mechanism projects in developing countries. If passed, the bill will enable Australia to enjoy the benefits that flow from meeting our international obligations under the Kyoto protocol. This is not a debate about Right or Left. This is a debate about right and wrong. It is a debate about old ways or new paths. It is not a debate about blame; it is a debate about real solutions to problems that are real now, but potentially catastrophic if not addressed. Average global temperatures have risen by 0.6 degrees over the past century. The 10 hottest years on record have all been in the last 14 years. Glaciers that have not retreated since the last ice age 12,000 years ago are now doing so. Australians can already see the kinds of impacts that will only get worse as warming advances: the four-year drought, the drop in rainfall in Western Australia, Kakadu being flooded by salt water, and coral bleaching of the Great Barrier Reef. Experts predict that Australia is going to get progressively drier over the coming century. According to the CSIRO, climate change will only worsen drought conditions. What Australia does in the next decade to avoid dangerous climate change will deterwill mine the fate of our economy, our environment and our way of life. Ratification of Kyoto is not only good for the environment it is good for the economy. That is why the Prime Minister proclaimed in 1997, when Australia signed the Kyoto protocol, that Kyoto was a win for the environment and a win for Australian jobs. The Prime Minster was right then but he is wrong now. The potential for innovation and therefore business investment and growth is immense. With the right policy framework, it has the potential to unleash new commercial forces and unforeseen economic opportunities. By not ratifying, Australia is giving the world a jump-start on entry to a dynamic driving force of 21st century economies. Australian companies and our economy will be disadvantaged if we exclude ourselves from carbon markets and the developing renewable energy technology markets. The investment will simply go elsewhere. Pacific Solar has already moved to Germany. Businesses that want to take advantage of the clean development mechanism provisions are already establishing themselves in New Zealand. Emissions trading is the most efficient way of achieving outcomes because it reduces the cost of reducing emissions and therefore provides the most effective method of encouraging action. That is why state and territory governments have agreed on a framework to introduce a state based scheme. But it requires national leadership. The Howard government's response has been to abolish the Australian Greenhouse Office-confirmed in the last budget. Were it not for the decisions of the Beattie and Carr governments to stem land clearing, Australia would not meet our Kyoto target. Given that Australia will meet our generous target, it is absurd that Australia remains on the outside looking in. Like almost every international agreement Australia is part of, it is not perfect. But it is an important first and it is the only game in town. Labor believes that Australia is missing out on significant opportunities by not ratifying the Kyoto protocol. It is in the interests of our economy, our health and the international community for us to sign up and ratify Kyoto immediately. We need to become part of the coalition of the willing when it comes to tackling climate change, and I call for a full debate and a vote on this bill.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: AVOIDING DANGEROUS CLIMATE
text: Is the motion seconded? Mr Garrett-I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: Dr JENSEN
Title: AVOIDING DANGEROUS CLIMATE
text: I begin by stating that, in the very title of the Avoiding Dangerous Climate Change (Kyoto Protocol Ratification) Bill 2005, the member for Grayndler is seeking to reinvent accepted scientific vernacular to fit his party's ideology. The term ‘dangerous climate change' allows an any-way bet and can be used whatever the climatic changes that occur. After all, the only real certainty about climate is that it will change over time. I refer to an article by Andrew Bolt which was published in the Herald Sun on 9 February this year. It states that Greenpeace has, in recent years, replaced the term ‘global warming' with ‘climate change' in its press releases. The threat of global warming is not as strong as it once was, so climate change is a more sellable term. The world's glaciers retreat and advance constantly over time. The totemic Upsala Glacier, which Greenpeace uses in its rant about global warming, has actually seen no warming at all since scientists began study. Glaciologists working at this glacier utterly reject global warming as the cause of this glacier's retreat. In fact, up until the mid1970s there was a general scientific belief that the world was due for another ice age. A step, report prepared for the US congress in 1978 agreed with the National Academy of Sciences that ‘in geological perspective, the case for cooling is strong-we may reasonably suppose the world is about to slide into the next ice age'. The member for Grayndler and the member for Kingsford Smith think that dangerous climate change-this newly invented termis the greatest threat facing humanity. Yet they reject nuclear energy as part of the solution. The member for Kingsford Smith had a band called Midnight Oil. Given his position on nuclear energy, he should have joined the band whose theme song was Living in the Seventies. It is difficult to know, however, who would be the lead singer and who would be on backing vocals-the member for Kingsford Smith or the member for Grayndler. The rest of the Labor Party would make up the band, although the resultant sound would more aptly be described as a caterwauling cacophony than something melodious to most Australian ears. Nuclear energy is a safe solution, especially with the inherently safe generation IV reactors, which make meltdown impossible, and synroc, an Australian invention which mimics rock that has safely stored radioactive waste from a natural nuclear reactor in Africa for two billion years. Synroc can store high-grade radioactive waste for geological periods of time. It is important to note that, after a period of hundreds of years-and certainly not the figure of 300,000-odd years that Greenpeace likes to push-high-grade nuclear waste will have radioactivity levels akin to the original yellowcake. Additionally, total radioactivity levels on earth are slightly lower after the nuclear power process-in other words, nuclear power generation does not add to overall radioactivity levels on earth at all. It would appear that the opposition sees its place as being negative: voicing problemsas it sees them-but never actually coming up with any solutions. Instead of the Kyoto rhetoric, the opposition should be embracing solutions, not rejecting them. This government will always put solutions above rhetoric-unlike the opposition, which seems intent on trying to make outdated rhetoric fit into a modern world. I urge the House to reject this bill, and I urge the opposition to become part of the solution rather than part of the problem.

Speaker: Mr GARRETT
Title: AVOIDING DANGEROUS CLIMATE
text: I rise to support the Avoiding Dangerous Climate Change (Kyoto Protocol Ratification) Bill 2005. I challenge the Prime Minister and senior ministers to support any of the comments we have just heard from the member for Tangney, which was one of the poorest efforts in debate in the House that I have yet witnessed. Since this bill was first read in the House, the wave of reports and increased knowledge in relation to threats posed by climate change just keeps coming. The Australian government has used the reduction in land clearing as a statistical fig leaf, but now it is fully exposed, with signifiing cant carbon dioxide increases anticipated over the next 20 years and beyond. To put it plainly, the bell is ringing loudly on climate change and the Howard government remains virtually immobile and mute. As state governments, individuals, communities, companies and, of course, the international community all commit to responding to the most important environmental challenge we face, we in Australia are stuck like shags on a rock-isolated and ineffective. We are failing the farmers and frustrating the efforts of those who are willing to invest, innovate and employ people in seeking solutions which address climate change-those people who want to act now. As the hot weather intensifies and the ice sheets melt and drop into the sea, as the clarion call goes out from the reputable scientific community for continued leadership and action, the Howard government is absent. It is doing nothing of consequence and saying nothing of consequence. It simply lacks the political nous to address immediately this issue. Faced with imminent change on a landscape scale, the government is incapable of facing up to the problems of living in a hothouse and addressing the effects that global warming is already having, and will increasingly have, on our natural plant and animal communities and our ecosystems. Where is the road map? Where are the plans? Where is the vision? All the government has on offer is a widely discredited white paper on energy, and a few voices who fly the nuclear power flag. Instead of articulating how Australia will address climate change, those on the other side, by embracing the nuclear option, want to replace the problem of the increasing level of carbon dioxide, which contributes to global warming, with another problem-namely, the creation of long-life radioactive waste. Judgfrom the debate in the House, this seems to be the extent of the government's thinking on this issue. What a tragic state of affairsand the longer the delay, the more difficult addressing this problem becomes. There are some clear ways forward which have been identified by Labor in this House and in this bill. We could bring Kyoto into law, establish a national emissions-trading scheme and understand the tremendous business opportunities that can be harvested with a national emissions-trading scheme. Recent modelling by Allen Consulting showed that a national emissions-trading scheme could reduce energy sector greenhouse pollution by 25 million tonnes by 2013. That would take five million cars off the road. Yet the government cannot act. We could increase mandatory renewable energy targets to a meaningful level, embrace deep cuts for carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases with legislation and time lines, and provide significant investment in renewable energy and efficiency. These are the solutions; these are the ways forward; these are the plans that the government needs to engage in. But we get nothing. We need to employ and engage the Australian community in this great task of addressing climate change, but the Howard government is nowhere to be seen. Our CSIRO regularly reports on this issue and on each occasion the message is clear: the scale and rate of climate change is rapidly being judged of an order too great to allow for timely adaptation by the natural world. But in the absence of leadership and thoughtful policy we are stuck, literally playing games with our future on earth as the Howard government, its ministers and its members are mute in the face of this great challenge. I say shame. I commend the Avoiding Dangerous Climate Change (Kyoto Protocol Ratification) Bill 2005 to the House. This is the action that we so desperately need but it is the resolute action this government is unable to provide.

Speaker: Mr KEENAN
Title: AVOIDING DANGEROUS CLIMATE
text: I rise to oppose the Avoiding Dangerous Climate Change (Kyoto Protocol Ratification) Bill 2005. I do so because I would never support a policy that sells out Australian workers and businesses. When I read the text of this bill, cannot help thinking that Labor have failed to heed the lesson of the last election campaign: that you cannot come in here and pretend to care about working people and then sell them out at the first available opportunity to the green movement-just as Labor did with Tasmanian forest workers and just as they are doing with this private member's bill today. In advocating the ratification of the Kyoto treaty, Labor seem hell-bent on sacrificing Australia's national interests and damaging Australia's future economic prosperity for a treaty that will have a very limited impact on the fight to restrict the emission of greenhouse gases. The paradox is that Australia's record on this issue is amongst the best in the world. We have met our Kyoto target without sacrificing economic growth. We have met our target without sacrificing Australian jobs. We have met our target without sacrificing Australian industry and without restricting investment. The problem with the Kyoto treaty is that it completely fails to provide a comprehensive or environmentally effective long-term response to this problem. It has no clear pathway for developing countries and as such would deliver only a one per cent reduction in the growth of global greenhouse gas emissions. What a farce! For this meagre reduction it would disadvantage Australia in relation to other nations, many of them our economic competitors. So, by advocating the ratification of the Kyoto treaty, the Labor Party are saying that they want to export Australian jobs and industry to the developing world. Rather than doing this, the coalition will continue to stand up for Australia because when we are making up our mind about policy it is Australian national interests that we prioritise. Labor prioritise an international protocol that will have a minimal effect on greenhouse gas emissions. Under the coalition, Australia will still I play a pivotal role in tackling this issue internationally whilst ensuring our record on environmental issues remains second to none. Indeed, Australia is firmly on track to meet its Kyoto target. The latest projections, released in December 2004, show that Australia's greenhouse gas emissions for the period 2008–12 are expected to be 108 per cent of 1990 levels, which is right on the mark. The Australian government has spent in total $1.8 billion on combating climate change. The latest projections show that this investment is delivering real results. Australia's economy is continuing to grow strongly but its greenhouse intensity is falling. In fact, under the coalition government our economy is projected to almost double over the 20 years from 1990. During this time our emissions are projected to rise by only eight per cent. Current measures are expected to reduce annual greenhouse gas emissions by 94 million tonnes by 2010, more than the equivalent of eliminating all emissions from the transport sector. We are now recognised as a world leader in addressing climate change. Our comprehensive climate change strategy delivers a clearly focused and integrated group of measures which covers emissions management, international management, climate change impacts, strategic policy support, science and measurement. The government's strategy encompasses strong, practical, broad based solutions to meet our greenhouse goals. It will deliver a lower greenhouse signature whilst maintaining a strong and growing economy. The Labor Party would have us believe that not ratifying the Kyoto treaty will limit the opportunities available to tralian businesses, but the opposite is in fact true. Ratifying the Kyoto treaty will mean that sensible projects run by Australian businesses that take substantial measures to limit their greenhouse gases will not be able to go ahead while the same projects would be able to go ahead in other nations that are not subject to such strict protocols. This means that companies will be restricted from operating in Australia yet they can go offshore and do whatever they like in certain nations without regard for the environment. It never ceases to amaze me that Labor, a party that professes to care about working people, is always prepared to sacrifice them to the green movement. Everyone in this chamber knows that once you strip away the rhetoric Labor is far more interested in appeasing people in Balmain than creating jobs in Boulder. It is far more interested in latte drinkers than lathe operators. The Labor alternative put up by the member for Grayndler will cost Australian jobs without addressing the issue of climate change. I, for one, am not prepared to sacrifice Australian workers to a treaty that completely fails to address greenhouse gas emissions. I oppose this ill-considered bill. (Time expired)

Speaker: Ms GEORGE
Title: AVOIDING DANGEROUS CLIMATE
text: I want to begin by expressing my amazement at the contributions of the last two government speakers, the members for Tangney and Stirling, to this debate on the Avoiding Dangerous Climate Change (Kyoto Protocol Ratification) Bill 2005. First of all, I find it really remarkable that two members from a state suffering the worse impacts of global warming can come into this House and, as the member for Tangney did, not accept the scientific fact of global warming. Cut to the quick, that is what his argument was about; he just does not accept the scientific fact of global warming. He then went on to trivialise the issue by suggesting that somehow we Aus- were obscuring the issue of the crisis of global warming by calling our bill ‘Avoiding Dangerous Climate Change'. But everybody out there in the community understands precisely what those words mean. Avoiding dangerous climate change means doing what we can as a nation in the national interest to avoid the serious impacts of global warming. One way that we propose to do that is the method proposed in the second reading speech on this private member's bill-that is, by ratification of the Kyoto protocol. Obviously, the member for Tangney does not believe in the scientific fact of global warming and, furthermore, believes that Australia should really consider one option alone for the future-that is, the nuclear option. That is a debate for another day. I, for one, do not concur with him; but it seems that he has put all his eggs in that basket rather than accepting the realities that there are a lot actions that can be undertaken to stem the tide of this global crisis. The member for Stirling then proceeds to suggest that somehow, by the ratification of the Kyoto protocol, this side of the House is selling out Australian workers. That is the most pathetic argument that I have ever heard in opposition to ratification-as pathetic as the member for Tangney defending his position by trying to rebut the established scientific facts. The real issue about employment opportunities is the fact that the ratification would enhanceMr Keenan-Rubbish!

Speaker: Ms GEORGE
Title: AVOIDING DANGEROUS CLIMATE
text: investment in green technologies and the employment options and opportunities that would go with it. Mr Keenan-It will ship Australian jobs offshore!

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: AVOIDING DANGEROUS CLIMATE
text: Order!

Speaker: Ms GEORGE
Title: AVOIDING DANGEROUS CLIMATE
text: I suggest that the member for Stirling actually have a look at what his own minister has said on this issue. I your position quite contradictory. The minister himself, in suggesting that Australia will meet the Kyoto targets without ratification, in fact argued that we were achieving this with no deleterious impact on the economy or on employment. You cannot have it both ways. We are strongly arguing that ratification would bring with it enormous employment and economic opportunities that this nation is forsaking by the government's failure to ratify the Kyoto protocol. The position advanced this morning is untenable, both on scientific grounds and on the grounds that clearly the members do not understand that the Kyoto protocol brings with it a carrot and stick approach. While the minister is, on the one hand, lauding our efforts on meeting the targets, he is forsaking of the opportunities that the protocol, through its various mechanisms, brings for investment and employment opportunities. Even if the two members in this House do not understand the significance of global warming, the Australian community does. It is very interesting that in a recent research finding, which I think was conducted by the Lowy Institute, the issue of global warming was rated by Australians as being more significant to them even than the issue of international terrorism. So it is only the other side of the House that does not understand the importance that the community places on this issue. I am surprised that members from a state like WA, already experiencing very severe impacts, could come into this House and pretend that it is not an issue. The Kyoto protocol is not the be all and end all of international efforts to deal with this global crisis, but it is a step in the right direction. It is a step in the right direction that, surprisingly, was acknowledged by your own Prime Minister back in 1997 when he said, at the time of signing up to the protocol, find that it was a win for the environment and a win for Australian jobs. The Prime Minister was right in 1997, but he is wrong now. The private member's bill that has been brought to this House tries to ameliorate the consequences of non-ratification. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr JENKINS
Title: AVOIDING DANGEROUS CLIMATE
text: In supporting the Avoiding Dangerous Climate Change (Kyoto Protocol Ratification) Bill 2005, introduced by the honourable member for Grayndler, I think that we have to go through some of the things that have been said by the other side of the chamber in rebuttal as reasons for not ratifying the Kyoto protocol. If the honourable member for Tangney is suggesting that there are no scientific facts surrounding the basis for the need to look at the problems covered by the Kyoto protocol, he should also understand that there is a great body of scientific evidence to the contrary. As I have said on many occasions in this place, in the scientific world it is not uncommon to have different views about certain facts. But the honourable member for Tangney has to realise that Australia and the international community cannot sit idly by and hear the observations about global worming-global warming!that are there and not take any action. Whether it be global worming or global warming, it is still an important phenomenon! The Kyoto protocol was an attempt by the international community to sit down and to work in a collegiate fashion to make sure that this problem was addressed. It is a simple analysis to look at the reasons for global warming and suggest that the element that prevents Australia from signing up under Kyoto is the loss of jobs. If there is a sector within the Australian community that might be affected by the Kyoto protocol, those issues can be directly dealt with. But the opportunities that exist for employment growth are outstanding. Those are the things that the government should be putting its mind to. Whether they be alternative energies or a whole host of other matters that go to the principles of making sure that global warming is reversed, these are the things that Australia, with the know-how of its research and development, can do and can do well. We have seen the phenomena addressed elsewhere in the parliament, with the House of Representatives environment committee encouraging the government on a bipartisan basis to go straight into the trading regimes and to increase MRET, because these things can lead to the encouragement of job development in other sectors where we have not had the wit to make sure that they happen. To simply look at industry as the main basis of the phenomenon of global warming and the carbon release is wrong. Let's look at the facts. Over the decade from the 1990s through to 2003, the transport contribution to the release of gases leading to global warming increased by 28.8 per cent. The stationary energy-that is, the non-transport energy-is 37 per cent. These are the issues that we have to address. We cannot just have members like the honourable member for Tangney saying that nuclear power is going to be the be-all and end-all and the saviour. At the end of the day, some of the other interesting facts relate to the oil shortage that we are confronting. The way in which the demand is increasing and access to oil energy is decreasing globally means-and it has been illustrated to me in a briefing today-that by 2030 the shortfall between what is expected to be needed from oil energy and what will be available is the equivalent of thousands and thousands of nuclear power plants. But the point is that that could not be used for the purposes of transport et cetera. As a nation and a global community, the ratification of the Kyoto protocol is a way we can look at this problem positively. Debate interrupted.
