Speaker: Mr TRUSS
Title: FARM HOUSEHOLD SUPPORT
text: Wide Bay-Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry) (7.30 pm)-by leave-I move: That this bill be now read a third time. Question agreed to. Bill read a third time. NA ARRANGEMENTS (FOREIGN-OWNED BRANCHES AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 2005 Returned from the Senate Message received from the Senate returning the bill without amendment or request. NA NA AMENDMENT (FAMILY ASSISTANCE AND RELATED MEASURES) BILL 2005 Consideration of Senate Message Message received from the Senate acquainting the House that the Senate does not insist upon its amendments disagreed to by the House of Representatives to the Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (Family Assistance and Related Measures) Bill 2005 and has agreed to the bill. NA COLLEGES (FLEXIBILITY IN ACHIEVING AUSTRALIA'S SKILLS NEEDS) BILL 2005 Second Reading Debate resumed from 16 June, on motion by Mr Hardgrave: That this bill be now read a second time. upon which Ms Macklin moved by way of amendment: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: “whilst not declining to give the bill a reading, the House condemns the Government for: (1) creating a skills crisis through its continued failure to provide the necessary opportunities during their nine long years in office for Australians to get the training they need to decent job and meet the skills needs of the economy; (2) failing to train enough Australians in areas skill shortage and relying on skilled migration; (3) exacerbating this crisis by failing to introduce Budget measures to train more Australians now, including Labor's Trade Completion Bonus for traditional apprentices; (4) making Australian business wait until 2010 for the Technical Colleges to produce their first qualified tradesperson; (5) failing to double the number of school-based traditional apprentices and provide extra funding to support schools in taking up the places; (6) failing to further invest in our world-class school and TAFE systems to create opportunities for young Australians to access high quality vocational education and training at all schools, not just 24 Australian Technical Colleges; (7) its uncooperative and hostile attitude towards the States and Territories in establishing these Colleges, despite the central role the States and Territories will play in any successful operation; (8) failing to provide new support to other regions that also have high youth unemployment, an industry base and skill shortages, but are not listed for a Technical College; and (9) inappropriately using vocational education and training as a vehicle through which to drive their ideological industrial relations agenda which bears no relation to successful student outcomes”.

Speaker: Mr WOOD
Title: AUSTRALIAN TECHNICAL
text: To continue my speech on the Australian Technical Colleges (Flexibility in Achieving Australia's Skills Needs) Bill 2005: principals of second colleges will have the autonomy to make key staffing and financial decisions relating to the functioning of their college. This level of authority will promote ownership of the college and real responsibility for the model's get a success. La Trobe is one of the fastest growing electorates in the country, with up to 50 families moving into the area each week. The of increase in the number of families in our local community has ensured that there are demands for all levels of education, including secondary. Will technical colleges compete with the TAFE system? The system devised for technical schools is to complement the TAFE system, not compete with it. Currently in La Trobe there is only one TAFE in the area, located in Berwick, which is at the heart of the population growth area. Berwick TAFE is a great learning institution within the electorate and forms part of the Chisholm Institute, which offers tertiary education to the people of the south-east suburbs of outer Melbourne. This local campus does not cover all areas offered by TAFE, though. It offers courses covering business; HR and marketing; working with the community, including aged care services; IT; engineering; beauty therapy; and sport and recreation. These courses are mainly professional courses, but not trades. There is a distinct lack of tertiary education in trades and therefore a skills shortage in our local community. Berwick campus does not offer the VCE; therefore, our young people miss out on the opportunity to do the VCE through TAFE. Also located in Berwick is a campus of Monash University. This is a new campus of Monash University which my predecessor, Bob Charles, was instrumental in bringing to La Trobe. For young people who want to study locally beyond VCE we have Berwick TAFE and Monash University. For young people who do not want to go on to further study, there is a distinct lack of opportunity. Statistics show that not all young people aspire to complete university or TAFE studies. According to the 2001 census, the breakdown of academic qualifications for La Trobe is: tertiary education, 17.6 per cent; trade qualification, 19.2 per cent; and no qualification, 52.9 per cent. These figures show that not all young people want to go to university or TAFE. More of my young constituents have gone and developed a trade. I believe we can get more of our youth to take up a trade and to begin to address our skills shortage. By building technical colleges, we can help young people develop these skills while they are pursing their academic studies, and finish high school with an academic qualification in addition to an employable trade. This concept is well received in the La Trobe area by schools and by the business community. I have met with several groups within my electorate about the possibility of developing technical schools in the electorate. I met with Vin Feeney, who is an excellent ambassador and Principal of St Joseph's College in Ferntree Gully, to discuss the possibility of a technical school within the college. The Shire of Cardinia is interested in a college for their local community. I met with Mayor Gary Runge and Paul Dimasi, CEO of South East Learning Network, to discuss this proposal. Haileybury College in the city of Casey is also keen to develop the idea of a technical college. I have also had discussions with Principal Greg Holman from Upwey High School, who is a fantastic principal. He is offering year 11 and 12 students school based apprenticeship programs through the TAFE network. The school currently has 120 students undertaking vocational education training at Box Hill TAFE, outside the electorate, in areas such as hospitality, electronics, electrical, multimedia, sport and fitness. Students at Upwey High School would love to undertake courses in trades such as building and plumbing through the school based apprenticeship program in conjunction with the TAFE system. However, the current program in these trades is only offered at the certificate III level. To offer these trades at the certificate III level is problematic. Wage structure and the range of entitlements that must be offered to these students, including holiday pay, overtime and payment to attend TAFE, to name only a few, make it very expensive for employers to take on students through this program and therefore there is not a lot of interest from employers to be involved. If this program was able to run at the cergreat tificate II level, which does not incur the same level of entitlements, Upwey High School students would be eager to undertake courses in trades such as building and plumbing. As the current school based apprenticeship program is limited to courses that are offered through TAFE, there is a demand for technical colleges designed to provide our young people with trade skills. The lack of public transport makes it difficult students to undertake these courses in places such as Box Hill, which is why we need colleges designed to teach technical skills in our local area. This has been a popular program, indicating a need to take the next step-to build specifically designed colleges to cater to these needs for skilled education. To cater people from all areas of my electorate we would need to build a technical college in the Berwick-Beaconsfield area as well as in the north of the electorate in or around the Boronia-Ferntree Gully area. There is a distinct lack of public transport from the north of the electorate to the south so we would need a technical college in each of these areas to cater for all students I speak from experience with my technical school background. I attended Ferntree Gully Technical School from year 7 to year 11. This school offered great opportunities for many former students in college at that time. It offered a great deal of diversity whether be carpentry or plumbing. Unfortunately, the school closed on 31 December 1996 along with around 400 other schools, which were closed to save money. I can also go back to my experience as a police officer. I was interested to hear the member for Lyons raising some objections. But one thing as a police officer that I have noticed is that some people do not ordinarily fit into the education system and they have learning difficulties. If they can be catered for in a technical college they will not fall through the gaps in the education system. They will not leave school early. They will not get involved in crime and subsequently in drug abuse. These are the students we need to capture. These are the ones I strongly support. In closing, I support this bill. It is a great step forward to address the skills shortage. More importantly, as I have stated, it for will capture those who are falling through the gaps in the education system and give them a trade and a future.

Speaker: Mr BEVIS
Title: AUSTRALIAN TECHNICAL
text: Brisbane) (7.39 pm)Apprenticeship training and technical and further education are extremely important aspects of the fabric of Australian society. They are important for the individuals who for participate in them. They can very well determine life expectancy outcomes and career outcomes and of course they are important nationally because without the skills that are provided through those important training and education programs our national economic growth would be impeded. They are far too important to become victims of the political games that this government has actually turned them into. The bill that is before us at the moment arises from a policy statement made by the Liberal Party in the lead-up to the election, that for the first time the national government would establish its own technical colit leges. Twenty-four are to be established as a result of this bill, providing for up to 7,200 students in years 11 and 12 equivalents. In the typical Orwellian fashion that we have become used to with this government, the bill is also cutely titled, as much of their less friendly legislation is. So this bill is officially titled: Australian Technical Colleges (Flexibility in Achieving Australia's Skills Needs) Bill 2005. Anybody who thinks this is about achieving our skills needs needs only to look at the government's actual record in dealing with this problem. There is an acute shortage in skills in a number of key sectors, particularly in a number of the traditional trades, that is impeding the opportunities of business in Australia. It is impeding the opportunities we have for production and export. That skill shortage is in no small measure an outcome of the failure of this government to invest in the skills training opportunities that governments in the past have accepted their responsibilities to support. In the period between 1995 and 2001 the public investment in higher education in Australia actually fell by over eight per cent. That beggars belief. There are few countries in the OECD for whom that is the case. Most countries in the OECD during that period from 1995 through to the start of this decade increased their commitment to higher education because they understood the importance of investment in people's skills to provide for national growth and, of course, the greater opportunities it presents for individuals to enjoy a higher standard of living and a more fulfilling career whilst they are at work. But, nearly uniquely in the OECD, the Howard government has the record of reducing public investment in higher education. Little wonder that we now have a skills crisis on our hands, a skills crisis that is now recognised across the community, by employers, by unions and by all sides of politics. It is a skills crisis that in no small measure has been produced by the Howard government's own ineptitude in dealing with higher education. It is, I think, no accident that this bill rors a document produced by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry that was published earlier this year. When you have a look at the migration of former Howard government staffers into the senior positions within ACCI it is no surprise that ACCI would produce a document that the Liberal government would pick up virtually unaltered. The bill we have before us fits into that category. The bill proposes not to support those training institutions that are in desperate need of financial support to meet this skills shortage. It proposes instead to spend money establishing a parallel system. This is not a complementary system; this is a parallel system that in one sense duplicates what is done in many secondary schools. I know in the state of Queensland students are able to undertake trade qualification courses at the same time as they do the normal year 12 leaving certificate. It duplicates that and it duplicates some of the activities that are presently undertaken in TAFE colleges. Why does it do that? Not because it is the most effective and efficient way to deal with our skills shortage but because this government has developed a fixation on trying to ride the states, on trying to ensure that its dogmatic doctrinaire policies are able to be forced upon the states and, indeed, upon companies whether they like it or not. One of the things that concerns me about this whole process is that the year 12 certificate that students will get on completion of their studies at these new Australian technical colleges will not necessarily provide them with any opportunity to go to university. That concerns me for this reason: we are effectively streaming our children at age 15. We are saying to a 15-year-old person: ‘You must, at the age of 15, make a decision that has the potential to impact upon your life for decades to come.' As a parent and a former mirteacher, I take the view that that is not the best course of action for young people. Many of us in this place have been teachers; many more of us have children. Most of us know that your average 15-year-old is probably not best placed to make those decisions-but, in practice, that is what this legislation will make many of them do. At the ripe old age of 15 they will opt for a program that will cut off options for them into the future unless they undertake significant studies later in life, usually on a part-time basis. People can do that but, frankly, that is a more difficult road for people to take. I think it is an error to stream our young people, to typecast them in this way at such a young age. I have serious concerns about that. I also have concerns about this government's approach to these Australian technical colleges which mirrors their approach generally to education, in that the government intend to provide more funding for those institutions that are run by non-government organisations. We do not yet know where these Australian technical colleges will be or indeed who will be operating them, whether they will be new buildings and new institutions or whether they will simply be additions to and expansions of existing training facilities. What we do know is that the government have committed to provide more funds for those that are run by nongovernment organisations. Why is that the case? I look forward to the minister in reply explaining to the Australian people why it is that their tax dollars in establishing these ATCs should go in greater largesse to the non-government sector than to the government sector. That raises an interesting point. In operating these Australian technical colleges is the non-government sector going do that as a benevolent activity or as a profit-generating venture? The shadow minister, the member for Jagajaga, Jenny Macklin, quite correctly pointed out the attitude of the private providers. She referred to the comments of the Australian Council for Private Education and Training, who said: It would need to be a commercial arrangement ... where there needs to be the opportunity to costs and have a return for the operator ... In other words, run them at a profit. So this bill will establish Australian technical colleges in competition with and duplication of existing TAFE colleges and services provided through TAFE courses run in secondary schools around the country. At least in part, it will do it on the basis of providing more money to the private sector to run these ATCs and on the basis that those private sector operators will seek to get a return on their investment, as they would for any other private venture. I do not think that is the best way to deliver outcomes in education and training. But that is the approach that the government has opted to take. Of course, one the great failings of this government's approach to dealing with the skills shortage is that this bill, heralded by government members in this debate and outside the parliament during the election campaign, will not produce a single tradesperson until 2010-not one. We have a crisis today because of the government's neglect over the course of the last 10 years-and this bill, which the government herald as addressing that, in fact does nothing to address the skills shortage until 2010. There are things that they could be doing without spending this amount of money. For example, there is a crisis with noncompletion. Between 25 and 30 per cent of all people who start apprenticeships do not complete them. That is a wasted skill that this nation is missing out on. Labor has announced its policy to provide completion bonuses to students undertaking those courses to encourage them to stay on and complete their studies. That is a real dollar incentive, so that those people who start out on this opportunity to create a career for themselves in a trade and complete it will get a financial reward from the government when they do. That would actually provide additional tradespeople next year cover and the year after, but under the government's approach we will wait until 2010 before there is one additional tradesperson as a result of this legislation. If that is not bad enough, the government's approach to our skills shortage has been not only to ignore the Australians in this situation but to try to plug the hole through a massive increase in skilled migration. Since 1998 there has been an increase in skilled migration of a whopping 178,000 people. Mr Hockey-What's wrong with that?

Speaker: Mr BEVIS
Title: AUSTRALIAN TECHNICAL
text: I happen to be a supporter of an increased migration policy not a decreased migration policy. I am happy to stand here on the record and say I would rather see more people coming to our shores. What is wrong with it, Minister, is that at the same time as the government did that they turned away about 270,000 Australians from TAFE colleges as unmet demand. There was a demand in TAFE colleges throughout this country over the same period of time of a quarter of a million plus Australians who could not get into do a TAFE course because the system was not properly funded and resourced. At the same time, we import 178,000 people to do those tasks. That is fundamentally flawed. I do not think most people in Australia believe that is the way that this should be done. But the Howard government's real intent with this legislation is exposed by their desire to micromanage the entire thing. Nowhere is that more evident than in their requirements to have their industrial relations policies included as part of the conditions of funding for these new institutions. The Liberal Party in government are using their funds-their grants to the states, their contracts with private companies-to force people onto individual contracts whether or not they want it or whether or not their employer wants to offer it. We have seen already on a number of occasions that the government have attempted to do that with universities. Basically, they have required universities to offer employment arrangements that the universities do not think are appropriate to them and that they do not wish to offer. The government have required them to do that for fear of loss of funds. But it is not just in connection to funding that the government has done that. I can well recall Ian MCLachlan, when he was Minister for Defence, requiring a contract of the Australian Navy to be renegotiating just after it was signed because the contract provided for the employees to be engaged under a collective agreement. The department, under instructions from the minister, renegotiated that contract, requiring people to be employed on individual contracts. The Commonwealth actually had to pay penalties for breaching the contract and having it rewritten. The government went out of its way, and the taxpayers paid more money, to force workers onto a contract system that they did not want to be on, and to force employers to offer it when it was not their wish. We are seeing the same thing happening in these new technical colleges. In the end, these new technical colleges are going to provide a take-it-or-leave-it offer: if you want the job you must sign the AWA. Of course, one of the great jokes about AWAs is that they are not individual contracts. You find that all AWAs are the same. They come off the word processor and the person's name is inserted. One of the more memorable examples that came to light was an AWA that included maternity leave which was offered to a male person. When the individual said that he did not think that was appropriate he was told that if he wanted the job he would sign the contract and shut up. That is how individual they are! These are conditions that are across the board but when the negotiations occur all the power is on one side of table. This is the government's effort to force their industrial relations policy into a sector of education that they have previously been unable to crack. I take my hat off to the government for their willingness to manipulate all of the powers at their disposal to force their industrial relations policy on workers and on companies. When I look back I think that the Labor government was far too timid in our pursuit of some of these things! Having been in a couple of positions in relation to this over the years, the one piece of advice I would give the government is that the further you push the pendulum in one direction the greater is the pressure to push it back further the other way-and quicker. I actually look forward to the opportunity to pick up the processes that this government have put in place. I look forward to the opportunity, as part of a Labor government, to use precisely the same mechanisms that this government have employed to ensure that Labor's platform of reform is implemented by contractors, companies and governments, whether they happen to think it is right or not, because that is the approach that this government have adopted. What is good for the goose is good for the gander. There is a message here for those people in ACCI and elsewhere in the chorus of support that this government have around them when these issues come out-the people, like ACCI, who have in the past put out their press releases before the documents were published. That message is that when there is a change of government, as there inevitably will be-we live in a democracy; there will be a change of government-the new government will find that this Howard government have set new benchmarks for the way in which the federal government can tie the hands of contractors, people wanting to do the business with government and the states. I think that is a very dangerous road that the government have decided to go down, but it is obvious from recent statements-and it will become more obvious to all of us after 1 July-that that is exactly the approach that they intend to take. On that point I take my hat off to the government for their willingness to use all of the levers at their disposal to ensure that their policies, however doctrinaire, are imposed on the community at large. It may well be that the community at large do not appreciate that and there may be a backlash against the government for doing it. I noticed in the bill one interesting provision which provides extraordinary power to the minister. In paragraph 6(2) the legislation talks about agreements with the states for these Australian technical colleges. It says: An agreement may also specify other conditions, and that the payments under this Act are made on those conditions. That is a section of the act that talks about the conditions under which payments can be made. So after reciting the things that you would expect would be in a bill like this, it then basically says that whatever the minister wants to set as a condition can be set. I will read it again. It says: An agreement may also specify other conditions, and that the payments under this Act are made on those conditions. I thought, ‘That's an interesting provision in the bill; I'll have a look at what the government memorandum says.' People listening are probably not familiar with the process. When bills are introduced the government also publishes an explanatory memorandum which is supposed to explain the details of what is in the legislation. The relative part of the explanatory memorandum says: Subclause 6(2) provides that an agreement may also specify other conditions and that the payments under the Act are made on those conditions. If that sounds familiar it is because it is an identical reprint of what is in the act. So the explanation of the act, that the government have provided, is the words of the act. Why are they being coy about this? They are being coy because that is the catch-all. That is the provision in this bill that will enable the ister to force whatever conditions the government want onto the institutions that will be running these ATCs. That clause gives the government of the day the power to impose whatever condition they want, without limit. That is an extraordinary provision to put into a funding arrangement with the states or with private education providers, but that is the process that the government have put in place. The final thing of concern that I want to mention is that, when the government announced they were going to go down this path, they told the Australian electorate that there would be an open tender process. There has not been an open tender process. Instead of that there has been a request for proposals evaluated behind closed doors and with no public scrutiny. No-one in this parliament at this point-other than, I guess, a few in the cabinet-know where the colleges are going to go. I listened to the member for La Trobe, in the second reading debate, rattle off half a dozen places in his electorate that wanted to have one of these colleges. I hope he has gone to tell them that they will get one, because he will end up eating crow in a hurry. There is no open process for this. This is a con. Technical and further education apprenticeship training is vitally important to this nation. We should not be using it as a political football or as some lever for doctrinaire ideological pursuits the way this government is by setting up these ATCs and forcing its industrial relations policies on people in the education sector through the colleges. To invest in education is a good thing. It is not possible, in my view, to spend too much money on education and training. You can spend a little bit and waste all of it, but if you spend it properly there is no such thing as a population too well educated and too well trained.

Speaker: Mr RICHARDSON
Title: AUSTRALIAN TECHNICAL
text: I rise today in support of the Australian Technical Colleges (Flexibility in Achieving Australia's Skills Needs) Bill 2005. This bill will deliver on the Howard government's election promise to provide 24 Australian technical colleges throughout the nation and is part of the government's overall attempt to address skills shortages across the nation. These technical colleges will provide to young people who wish to gain a trade the option to gear their year 11 and year 12 studies towards obtaining formal qualifications in that trade. There can be no greater testament to my support of this bill and this Howard government initiative than my support for a local consortium in my electorate of Kingston which has applied to have a technical college located in the southern suburbs of Adelaide. In the last two years the southern suburbs of Adelaide have seen the shutdown of a Mobil oil refinery and a local Mitsubishi plant. Since the closure of these two massive contributors to the southern economy-and the loss of over 800 jobs from these two closures alone-federal, state and local governments, along with private industry and the wider community, have developed a blueprint to grow and develop our local economy. One of the central points of that blueprint is the need for a strong skills and technology base. The southern region of Adelaide has 15,883 businesses, of which 1,222 specialise in manufacturing. That is two per cent higher than the state average. Despite the massive job losses that we as a region have suffered in recent times, local business associations, individual employers and job brokers continually report a critical level of skills ages throughout the area. These shortages are particularly evident in the metal trades, automotive, electrical and construction sectors, all of which are being targeted by this bill. Young people across my electorate of Kingston are screaming out to access this type of training. In the southern suburbs of Adelaide there are around 50,000 young people aged between 15 and 24. This bill targets up to 7,200 students a year, with 24 colleges proposed nationally. If a technical college were located in my electorate, it would provide places for 300 students a year. This is something that Kingston, in the southern suburbs of Adelaide, with such a large youth population, is screaming out for. The technical colleges proposed in this bill will provide a huge boost for communities in my electorate. Technical colleges provide hope not only to the young people who desperately wish to pursue a trade and who are struggling with the challenges of academic study but also to their families. They provide hope to local businesses who, if they increase production and create a successful business, will be able to source enough skilled labour and they provide hope to the community as a whole. Communities which have suffered massive job losses and plant closures, such as those of Mobil and Mitsubishi in Kingston, suffer a massive slump in morale and community spirit. Locating a technical college in my electorate and in others like it could provide a massive boost for communities nationwide. This initiative is aimed at training young men and women for the careers they want and getting them into jobs. These colleges will establish links with local industry to provide a pathway from training to work for these young people. I can assure you that local industry in my electorate is exceptionshortally supportive of this proposal, with many local companies and businesses providing letters of support for the organisations which have applied to establish a technical college. I have no doubt that the businesses in my electorate are typical of most businesses across the nation and are exceptionally supportive of this proposal. If this bill is passed, the first Australian technical colleges funded under this program will open their doors in 2006, with all 24 being operational by 2008. This is an immediate solution to some very immediate problems across the nation, including the skills shortage. There is no downside to this proposal. It allows young men and women, many of whom are frustrated by a structured academic learning environment and at risk of leaving school, to obtain their formal year 12 qualification while also obtaining skills which will qualify them for a trade. This proposal takes young people from a learning environment which does not suit them, and puts them in one which does. It enables young people to train for a trade and gives them links to local business so that they have direct access to jobs. It provides businesses with trained young people who are ready and willing to work, and it helps to address the skills shortage which is being faced across the nation. There is no downside to this bill. It is a great initiative by the Howard government, and it has my full support. For the benefit of electorates such as mine, for the benefit of every young person who wants to learn a trade, for the benefit of businesses who need trained young people and for the benefit of this nation, I commend this very important bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr ADAMS
Title: AUSTRALIAN TECHNICAL
text: The purpose of the Australian Technical Colleges (Flexibility in Achieving Australia's Skills Needs) Bill 2005 is to implement the government's election commitment to establish Australian technical colleges for years 11 and 12 students in 24 regions throughout Australia. These colleges are supposed to offer high-quality training and facilities that will further strengthen Australia's vocational education and training system and promote pride and excellence in acquiring trade skills. The government says the establishment of these colleges is a step in addressing the needs that Australia is experiencing in a number of traditional trades throughout the country. The bill provides for funding agreements between the Australian government and the colleges that can be tailored to the needs and challenges of each region. While some governance and administrative requirements will be set as standard conditions in each funding agreement, the bill apparently does not prescribe any particular model to operate in any region. There are some hidden problems in all of this. I gather there are changes that would reduce the learning environment for trade qualifications, which means that courses that normally take, say, four years with appropriate on job training and work site experience will now possibly take only three-and who knows what it will be in a few years; it may be two. I think we will be de-skilling the work force of Australia, particularly our young people, by casualising their training so they do not have the rigour of courses that are currently given in the TAFE system right around Australia. Additional funding is being found for the Australian technical colleges initiative. Appropriations totalling $343.6 million over five years will provide for the allocation of funds to the colleges to support infrastructure development as well as meet the additional costs associated with the delivery of the specialised services that the colleges will provide. Presumably, that money will be taken away from the TAFE training area and from the growth that TAFE should have been experiencing in recent times. That is the reason we have a shortage of skilled people in Australia. The bill is complementary to the Schools Assistance (Learning TogetherAchievement Through Choice and Opportunity) Act 2004, through which the colleges may receive general recurrent grant funding skill in addition to supplementary funding. The supplementary funding is predicated on staff having to sign Australian workplace agreements which leave unions out of negotiations. For the people that will be working in the colleges there will be no tenure and no job security. Staff will be able to be picked up and thrown away at will-hardly good for stable workplace relations and also hardly good for an environment that good teachers and people can warm to. The colleges are to have a governing body chaired by a local business person and consisting of local industry and community representatives that will ensure that the skills taught to students will be directly relevant to the needs of local industry, yet the unions that cover the trade skills and know the needs of industry inside out will be totally left out, being excluded from any input whatsoever. Each college which is a nongovernment school is supposed to be registered as a school in the state or territory in which it operates and accredited to deliver curriculum leading to achievement of the senior secondary certificate of education. But the state and territory governments are not convinced that they need these extra training facilities. It would be far better to expand the role of TAFE colleges and use their excellent resources, equipment and history to bridge this school to work gap, and it is a shame that we have not been able to get governments to talk together to make these things happen. I believe that even at this late stage talks should be going on. These features are supposed to allow the colleges to establish themselves as centres of excellence and to raise the profile and status of vocational pathways in schools, but the colleges are likely to be out on a limb and not part of the mainstream education system. This can only be seen as being exactly the same situation as that of the Australian School of Fine Furniture, which was established in Launceston by the Liberal Party, during one of its election spend-ups, to try to outdo a school run by the University of Tasmania in the south. The school in Launceston has now run out of money and has been bleating for more, and a bit has been supplied by the member for Bass. This school was established on an old model of one craftsman to one student. Although it is a useful way of teaching manual crafts, it is not practical or economic, given the sorts of costs involved in running it. As with other school based programs, the legislative base for the Australian technical colleges will be underpinned by funding agreements with either state or territory ernments or with the Australian Technical College Authority. The funding agreements will contain certain conditions under which funding will be allocated to colleges and will include a schedule of the payments to be made to each college over the term of the agreement. These conditions include forcing staff onto AWAs, which include taking away skills progression and pathway elements for teachers and will also probably include taking away the right to be a member of a union. Ongoing funding may also be contingent on colleges meeting specific eligibility critevide ria-so if you are not following the criteria on staff recruitment then the staff are the ones likely to cop the displeasure and be removed. This bill includes, as a condition of funding, a requirement for all colleges to provide reports covering financial expenditure and performance outcomes. This information, to be specified in the funding agreement, will include such information as the vocational education and training options being offered, academic outcomes, school leaver destinations and retention rates. The bill provides for an appropriation of $343.6 million over the period 2005 to 2009 to support the establishment and operation of the colleges. That is not a great deal over four years, especially if they are having to start from scratch, so I think it will be a long time before we see very much of these colleges and I believe this program is likely to be of little use in improving the training and skilling of Australia. I have some real concerns about the direction of these proposals-and I was also going to speak on the skills bill which was recently guillotined. I will mention some of the points I was going to make on that bill. I believe it is part of a very unpalatable package that is being forced onto Australia by this government. It seems to be giving the Comgov- monwealth the power of veto over state and territory governments in VET planning. In the past this approval process was conducted by the Australian National Training Authority. There were also some severe conditions placed on funding decisions. The question of choice of source of training could well be difficult for my state of Tasmania. Although the bill tries to provide more flexibility and competition for the providers of training, our state's small population would make it very difficult for providers to be able to keep standards up and prothe sort of training that suits the employer, as well as being affordable to both employer and apprentice. Centralised standards are okay in bigger states, but, of course, ANTA used to provide that flexibility to the smaller states by sharing training resources. I cannot see how a provider could survive if they had to play the market in Tasmania. The introduction of workplace reforms poses a similar problem. Because of other legislation, TAFE would be excluded, and there may be a problem in even allowing TAFE to be involved. TAFE has provided an excellent structure to deliver apprenticeships and training places for a very broad range of skills. This proposal is more likely to limit what training can be given in the state if ryone is competing for the basic competencies, because these are the basis of funding and pay for trainers. To have to adhere to complete implementation of competency based training rather than time based training requires the amendment of state legislation and awards to move to a completely competency based approach to VET, rather than a time based model. This would have a dramatic impact on the structure of the traditional apprenticeas ship system. Full competency based apprenticeships are strongly supported by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and opposed by the trade union movement. Increased flexibility and reduction in time, without a full competency based model, have been advocated by some states and have found some support within sections of the trade union movement, while being opposed by others. Another aspect is the fact that opening up the TAFE facilities to private VET providers could, once again, limit the sort of training given. There will be no ability to anticipate trade shortages in an overall package; it will be kept to immediate short-term needs as the market of the day requires. Planning future directions for TAFE will be left to no-one in particular-and I doubt whether Tasmanian TAFEs or any other training organisation with some credibility will survive. It will open everything up to real mickey mouse courses that we are now finding exist around the place. They cannot provide a career path by incrementally increasing skills, as on-thejob experience can mix with skill development and also income. Some of the other conditions pose difficulties for everyone, not just Tasmanians. These new funding arrangements have not been discussed with the states, so there has not been any opportunity to consider the full impact of many of the eveproposed conditions on the delivery of vocational education and training around the country. I am disappointed that ANTA is being abolished, because under ANTA there have been many programs that assist in the funding of adult literacy-programs that I, like many other people who missed whole chunks of schooling for many reasons, relied on to gain the skills that I lacked. I am not sure that these programs will be considered part of the new training schemes, as they are not directly requested by employers much of the time. It will again be left to the volunteers, who struggle to get resources for these programs, to organise who is going to do what and attract students who normally avoid any sort of learning like the plague because they are frightened to be a part of it. We are going to return to a society where those who had difficulties at school will be left at the bottom of the pile because, as hard as they try, there are no programs that cope with their particular problems. I do not mind any school or training institution being more open to the private sector, and I am sure there are ways and means to help boost the bottom dollar of those institutions, but if we do it at the expense of quality training then we should really think again. Many training areas are reliant on the community anyway to bring in realistic training modules and work very well in conjunction with local business or industry. Why do we want to upset this so much by introducing these measures? I have been looking at some of the training colleges that provide a haven for those who have dropped through the cracks of the ordinary training systems. Places such as Studentworks, in Launceston, and The Island, in Melbourne, have been highly successful and rely very much on good relations with all groups-federal, state and local governments, as well as unions, small business and industry. What is the future of these colleges under these new funding arrangements? This is not clear. I do not think individual work contracts for TAFE or technical training staff will have a bearing on the quality of the teaching, and it will only bring standards down to the lowest common denominator. People will be appointed on what they are prepared to work for, not what they have the best skills for. We really need to make some amendments to this bill if it is to work and provide proper access to training for all people. I believe should delete any reference to AWAs and individual contracts as part of the funding agreement. These contracts should not be related to good trainers, who would be put off by having to bargain for their jobs each year. I certainly cannot agree with government funding being reduced as a consequence of more developed entrepreneurial business planning, because I think the smaller states would lose out considerably and would probably close down many of the programs already operating quite successfully in their communities. I am still not happy with ANTA being disbanded, without knowing what is to be put in its place and whether it will have some overall standard and ability to coordinate a lot of courses in the country and to look at the overall training that takes place. TAFE has been an important part of tertiary training, and I am worried that it will lose its connection with other tertiary training institutions where students can access lines between the two. It is unfortunate that we have not built more links between TAFE and universities in Australia. I am unconvinced that any new colleges along the lines proposed by this bill are going to be more than just an expensive sideline to vocational education; the minister is trying to put a foot in the door to privatise college education. I do not believe that will work, Minister. The Labor Party have seen through that and it will be fought very strongly. We want a better deal for our kids, not one that is reliant on part-time teachers and casualised teachers and students who do not feel they have ownership of their jobs or a career path in their workplaces. I oppose the bill.

Speaker: Mr LINDSAY
Title: AUSTRALIAN TECHNICAL
text: I am pleased to have the opportunity to contribute to the debate on the Australian Technical we Colleges (Flexibility in Achieving Australia's Skills Needs) Bill 2005 this evening. Much has been said about Australian workplace agreements being part of the Australian technical colleges bill before the parliament tonight. I would like to inform the parliament that, two weeks ago, I was in the Pilbara at the West Angeles iron ore mine, which is a very large operation. There was not a single unionist in sight. The staff are all on AWAs. I have to say that it is an extraordinarily happy workplace. The No. 1 priority in that workplace is safety. It is the mantra of everybody on site, from the lowest paid to the highest paid employee. People there take safety seriously. The employees are happy with their jobs. The truck drivers on the site are being paid $120,000 a year to drive trucks at the mine. Yet the opposition continually paints AWAs as being somehow evil, that workers are disadvantaged and that things are not right in the workplace. But things are right. My experience at this iron ore mine brought home to me just how well AWAs can operate in all sorts of workplaces, and they can operate in that way in the proposed Australian technical colleges. In his contribution a moment ago, the member for Lyons said that people have to be on guard for their jobs because they may lose them under an AWA. I would point out a couple of things to the member for Lyons. The first thing is that employers do not lightly, if ever, try to terminate employees who are good workers. Particularly in an environment of very low unemployment, an employer cannot afford to terminate an employee for no good reason. So there is an inbuilt protection in relation to that. Certainly as a past employer of many years I always understood that staff were your best asset and that you did not just lightly terminate a staff member. The skills shortages that we see around the country exist just as much in Townsville and Thuringowa as they do anywhere else in the land. The emergence of skills shortages are a result of a complex set of factors and circumstances, including sustained economic growth under the Howard government, the globalisation of the economy, an ageing work force, a decline in fertility rates, a shift in labour market patterns, a poor image of the traditional trades and the low uptake of traditional trades by people historically not interested in the trades. Traditionally, a business cycle goes through a period of growth of approximately eight years, with a subsequent period of contraction, followed by another wave of growth. However, since the early 1990s, Australia's economy has experienced continued growth. Under the Howard government, that growth has built up pressure on the demand for skilled labour. Whilst Australia has been experiencing a continuing period of growth, the globalisation of economies has also occurred. This has resulted in global competition for professional, paraprofessional and skilled trades employees. The Australian Bureau of Statistics reports that some one million Australians now work overseas, which represents a significant net loss of skilled and professional workers for the Australian economy. In addition, during the 1990s, more than 250,000 young people were leaving school annually to join the work force or to undertake further education. It is expected that this will decline to 150,000 by 2010. Since the 1960s, fertility rates have also declined from average fertility rates of 3.5 babies per woman in 1961 to less than 1.9 in 1985 and to 1.7 in 2004. The contemporary trends embraced by government agencies and large businesses to maximise short-term returns with a focus on downsizing, outsourcing and corporatisation has led to a significant decline in investment in training by those agencies and businesses. Consequently, there has been a dramatic reduction in the number of apprenticeships being sponsored by these organisations. As Toner in 2003 suggested, the public sector accounts for around one-third of the decline in the intake of apprentices over the past 10 years. Similarly, the rapid growth of labour hire firms in response to these measures has resulted in Australia having the highest percentage of casualised workers in the industrialised world. It has long been acknowledged that the New Apprenticeships program has been successful in increasing participation in structured training and in opening up new and more flexible opportunities across occupations and industries that have not had a history of structured training. However, the recent evaluation of the New Apprenticeships scheme by the Department of Education, Science and Training, entitled Skills at work, recommended that further examination be undertaken on how growth in apprenticeships has related to the demand for skills in the economy. While there has been a recent increase in the uptake of trades by older workers, employers have tended to focus on young people, particularly school leavers, as their primary source of potential apprenticeship trainees. With the declining number of young people and the complexity of career pathways available, I believe that insufficient attention has been paid to attracting women, people with a disability, and Indigenous and older workers to the trades. All these are reasons why the Australian technical colleges will help fix the skills shortage in the economy, as I have outlined today. I certainly welcome a technical college in Townsville. I want to pay tribute to the Townsville Australian technical college consortium, who have put in a very good bid in the request for tender. This group was originally under the leadership of the Thuringowa City Council. I also pay tribute to Mayor Les Tyrrell and CEO Lyn Russell for their vision in strongly backing this opportunity provided by the government to have an Australian technical college in Australia's largest tropical city. A very keen and hard working executive group, chaired by Philip Begley, was formed as an interim steering committee to direct the participation of the request for proposal and tender and the business plan for the college. The Townsville Chamber of Commerce, engineering clusters, Catholic education, the Yalga-binbi-the Indigenous group for community development-the Housing Industry Association, the North Queensland region of councils and commerce, which is a very powerful group representing the sectors of the economy that the government was interested in attracting, all want to be part of this. There is now a nominated consortium membership, which includes FINPAC financial advisers, United Goninan, SunMetals, TAFE, Angus Knight, Queensland Nickel, James Cook University, Girvan Engineering and the Townsville Regional Group Apprentices Scheme. I am very pleased as the local member that such a powerful group has been assembled and has worked so very hard in putting forward to the government an outstanding bid. In the days and months ahead, all of those bids from around the Commonwealth will be assessed by Minister Gary Hardgrave, who has also done an outstanding job in steering this new proposal through the parliament to fruition. I know that Minister Hardgrave will be very proud when we see the first Australian technical college open early next year. The colleges will further strengthen Australia's vocational and technical education system and provide pride and excellence in the acquisition of trade skills. They will become centres of excellence in trade training, attracting capable and competent students who want to begin training for a career in the trades and who will also be completing their senior secondary education. In that sense, I report to the parliament that a number of state high schools in my electorate in Townsville very keenly embraced this concept. They want to be part of it. They want to see their students participating. They want them to get through years 11 and 12, but at the same time they want them to establish the fundamentals for a trade that they will be going into when they finish high school. I thank all school principals in Townsville and Thuringowa who have warmly welcomed and participated in the establishment of an Australian technical college in Townsville. I have been constrained by others in terms of how long I might speak. As there is another speaker, I will end my comments there. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr RIPOLL
Title: AUSTRALIAN TECHNICAL
text: I rise to speak on the Australian Technical Colleges (Flexibility in Achieving Australia's Skills Needs) Bill 2005 and to support the second reading amendment proposed by the member for Jagajaga which reads: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: “whilst not declining to give the bill reading, the House condemns the Government for: (1) creating a skills crisis through its continued failure to provide the necessary opportunities during their nine long years in office tralians to get the training they need to decent job and meet the skills needs of the economy; (2) failing to train enough Australians in skill shortage and relying on skilled migration; (3) exacerbating this crisis by failing to introduce Budget measures to train more Australians now, including Labor's Trade Completion Bonus for traditional apprentices; (4) making Australian business wait until 2010 for the Technical Colleges to produce their first qualified tradesperson; (5) failing to double the number of school-based traditional apprentices and provide extra funding to support schools in taking up the places; (6) failing to further invest in our world-class school and TAFE systems to create opportunities for young Australians to access high quality vocational education and training at all schools, not just 24 Australian Technical Colleges; (7) its uncooperative and hostile attitude towards the States and Territories in establishing these Colleges, despite the central role the States and Territories will play in any successful operation; (8) failing to provide new support to other regions that also have high youth unemployment, an industry base and skill shortages, but are not listed for a Technical College; and (9) inappropriately using vocational education and training as a vehicle through which to drive their ideological industrial relations agenda which bears no relation to successful student outcomes”. This bill provides for the establishment and operation of Australian technical colleges, ATCs, which is one of the government's a second election commitments-a commitment that was made in the heat and rush of an election campaign. While the result of that election campaign may well be known today, as in all election campaigns governments get very for Ausjittery about how they will fare and you get a could see them developing this policy on the run. The evidence of that was in the lack of detail and thought that went into the policy. areas of And now, as the government is developing this policy, we see the lack of connectivity within that which they are trying to achieve as well as the cut in the funding that was promised originally in the election campaign. The government has proposed just 24 colleges to be in operation by 2008. The government intends each college will accommodate up to 300 years 11 and 12 students, a total of 7,200 when fully operational, and implementation will be phased in from 2006. The Minister for Vocational and Technical Education has indicated that announcements on successful proposals to open colleges in 2006 will be made by the end of this month, with announcements regarding colleges to open in 2007 and 2008 to be made by the end of the year. The bill provides for funding agreements between government and the colleges. Funding will be dependent on a set of conditions, many of which are not detailed in this legislation. Colleges must be registered as schools under state and territory legislation and accredited to deliver the relevant senior school certificate, and as such you would have thought that government would have consulted and worked with the states ries much closer to ensure that the delivery of the senior school certificates is in line with educational principles right across the board and not just those of the federal government. The explanatory memorandumbut not the legislation-states that colleges must also be registered training organisations, RTOs, or must have formal links with an RTO to deliver the accredited training under a national training package qualification. It might be appropriate at this point note that, while the government is putting forward money for national training packages, it is the same government that strips money out of training and has also shut down the Australian National Training Authority. On the one hand, it reassumes responsibility and redistributes funds in the view of providing training, but in coming to that position it shuts down fine and worthy training organisations that have delivered many trained people to our economy. The bill appropriates $343.6 million over five years in supplementary funding for colleges over and above general recurrent schools and training funding. Other general recurrent funding will be payable to the ATCs by the Commonwealth under the Schools Assistance (Learning TogetherAchievement Through Choice and Opportunity) Act 2004 and by the states and territories through their relevant schools funding mechanisms and training funding under the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992. Although not mentioned in the bill, the government has indicated in both second reading speech and the explanatory memorandum that the conditions of funding will include industrial flexibility-I will come back to that in a minute-specifically provision for Australian workplace agreements and performance pay, and college principals will have responsibility for the employment of staff overseen by an industry and territoled governing authority. Whatever we might think of government, I am sure there are many fine people-in fact, at the end of my contribution I will make mention of a specific consortium in my electorate, the Springfield Education Citywho would be able to pull all this together and do something fair and equitable and be worthy of providing the sort of training that is required. But I am very concerned, as are many Labor members, about industrial flexito bility. What this means, and what we see again from the government, is that it is prepared to go to any length to achieve its ideological goals, even if it is at the expense of training, of skills, of investment in infrastructure and of developing the economy, developing people's lives, because without this so-called ‘industrial flexibility' that the government talks about and without its being in control of the industrial agenda the Australian technical colleges will simply not go ahead. We have seen this in other areas of infrastructure provision where the government puts a caveat that it will provide the money for schools or money for roads-desperately needed Commonwealth responsibility linked funds-not on the basis of need, because the need exists, but on the basis that ideology is followed through. I find that offensive and I find that not in the spirit or principle in which you would put together an Australian technical college of any description or any other package. If you are committed to the colleges, if you are committed to the training the and if you are committed to dealing with the skills crisis, then deal with it on its own merits. Do not wrap it up in something else; do not wrap it up in industrial relations conditions. Keep to the principle that you are trying to achieve. That is what the government should be doing, but that is not what the government is doing. There is a range of problems with this bill, and there are several contentious issues which Labor believes highlight the government's failure to address the nation's skills crisis. The government is investing $343.6 million over five years in Australian technical colleges at a time when it is offering no significant new funding for the Commonwealth-State Training Funding Agreement covering TAFE. You would have thought that any government seriously wanting to address a skills crisis sooner rather than later-now rather than later-would look at the existing structure and mechanism and say, ‘How can we the federal government actually participate and support the current system and even improve the current system?' What the government has done is a clever little act of deciding that, if it cannot have TAFE, if it cannot be TAFE, it will just create its own TAFE. We are going to have two parallel systems side by side, one which has been established for many decades and which is very successful but which is struggling in some areas and which could do with a healthy injection of funds and another, the Australian technical colleges, which are basically just a rebranding, a renaming, a rebadging. If people do not believe me on this and if they think that I am going a bit too far, all they have to do is look at the application forms, the supporting documentation for ATCs. The form says very specifically that the government is not looking for new infrastructure. It is not looking for new facilities or new buildings. It is not necessarily interested in building new things; it is interested in rebadging in its own image. The evidence of that is in the documentation, the application form. In the very first line, it says that ATC will be formed by a consortium of key educational providers ‘such as'-and the very first one it lists is TAFE. It is looking to TAFE to come in and be the provider. If it is good enough for TAFE to be a provider and part of a consortium, with schools, industry and so forth, it can do that. The Commonwealth can do that by negotiating with the states and with TAFE and delivering the same quality, resources and services to students as it otherwise would through its ATCs. I understand why the government would not want to do this: it does not have the Commonwealth moniker stamped on it. The government has stripped funding for roads away from local authorities as untied funding-ripped it out-and given it back through black spot and other funding. As long as it has a Commonwealth tag and you can put up a nice neat road sign that says ‘Money provided by the Commonwealth' or ‘Funded by the Commonwealth', it is okay. The intent is not to provide the skills, the training and the jobs; it is just to rebadge something in the Commonwealth's own image. It is a very frightening concept when you start to think that through. The documentation specifies 24 areas. It is important to look at where those areas are. They are a key indicator of the commitment of the government to training all Australians-its commitment to young people. In New South Wales, the ATCs will be in the Hunter, the Illawarra, Queanbeyan, Port Macquarie, Lismore, Ballina, Dubbo, Gosford and Western Sydney. It does not take a political genius to work out that they are in either marginal Labor seats that were targeted during the campaign or straight-out National Party or Liberal Party seats. In Victoria, there is Geelong, Warrnambool, Bendigo, Sunshine, Bairnsdale, Sale and eastern Melbourne-again in either, in the case of one or two, marginal Labor seats an which were targeted by the coalition during the election or, in the case of the rest, Liberal or National Party seats. Again, you do not have to be a political genius to work out the point of these in these particular areas. Fair dinkum: if you want to provide something for young people and deal with the skills crisis, do it on a needs basis, do it on a skills crisis basis, not on a political seat basis. In Queensland it is even worse. There is Townsville, in a marginal Liberal seat. There is Gladstone-and we have the member for Hinkler with us in the chamber tonight.

Speaker: Mr RIPOLL
Title: AUSTRALIAN TECHNICAL
text: Absolutely, a fine member. I am sure he is very happy to get an Australian technical college, as I would be in my electorate-as any of us would be, because we have been starved of Commonwealth funding for so long. Just a mere few crumbs would be enough to satisfy us. Just give us a little bit for our electorates. But of course there will be nothing in Oxley. We have Townsville, Gladstone, north Brisbaneagain marginal Liberal territory-and the Gold Coast. They are all in Liberal or National Party seats. Fair go! It is 100 per cent. Give us one. Don't our young people deserve skills? Don't our young people deserve to get a job? What is the go here? It is hard for the government. I ask them to explain this and give us some rationale as to why only people in Liberal and National Party seats deserve to have skills training and extra funding to try to deal with the skills crisis. I think not. In Western Australia it is even more dire. There are only two-Perth South, one of the most marginal seats in Australia, an ALP seat. I am sure the Liberal candidate at the time would have made hay as much as he could in trying to plug an ATC. It did not help him, though. And there is the Pilbara. Again it is 100 per cent. You are really going for the full gong. You expected to pick up the seat of Swan, but you did not. In Tasmania the coalition had to pick up some area. They had to look at one area, so they went for Northern Tasmania. Again, I do not have to go too far to explain this. And, in the Northern Territory, there is one in Darwin, another target area for the coalition. Fair enough. If you want to do something for skills and the skills crisis, do it but do it properly. Do it so that there is actually some benefit for young people. Do not do something that is based on the voting patterns of other people within those electorates. The government has failed in trying to deliver something wider and broader in this program. Government members made quite a bit of how workers are pretty safe-talking about the industrial relations connection-because we have low unemployment. But government members forget this: if you have a specific skill, yes, it is easy enough to get a job, but many workers out there are under a great deal of threat. If they work in a factory, as unskilled labour or in an area where there are many hundreds or thousands of employees, they do not weigh too much in the sort of power that bosses have over them. I would caution government members about the way they speak about workers, because they really do undermine their own position as well as that of workers in the way they fare in the power imbalance, as it were, between them and their employers. Other documentation-again, not in the bill-signals that infrastructure funding made available be subject to the Commonwealth's national code of practice for the construction industry. Again, the government is wrapping up ideology in trying to provide funding for skills. We are led to understand by this that, if it does not meet the Commonwealth's national code of practice for the construction industry because of a different state system, we simply do not get one. This is a real risk and a real problem for all those industry and education people who, in good faith, are putting forward consortium proposals that could be let down. We keep talking about the skills crisis and how long it takes to train people up-an apprentice takes four years and people in the health professions can take up to 10 years. It takes up to 10 years for a specialist and five or seven years for a doctor and so forth. That is a long time, so you really have to plan ahead. But you have now been in government for nearly a decade. When did government wake up to this? We have been beating the door of infrastructure and beating the door of the skills crisis, but it has been ling on deaf ears and now the government says, ‘It's going to take many years to do something.' What do you want-another 10? Do you want 20 years before you get something done? Is that how long it is going to take? I think the government ought to look back at its own record. Apart from an economy which was better in parts than most, as John Howard said when he came into office in 1996 and inherited the good economic reforms that the Hawke and Keating governments put in place, the government could have used that economic windfall to do something more than just give some money out to people close to election time. It could have done something strategic and given a bit of national leadership-not for today, because it is always easy to look good on the day. I am talking about five, 10 or 15 years down the track when people will look way back. They will look at the legacy and say, ‘Why didn't government make those tough decisions then about economic reform, about the skills crisis, about training needs and about what we needed to do to make sure that we had year after year, 14 years, of economic growth?' Reform was not delivered by this government-well acknowledged-but by the Hawke and Keating governments during the eighties and the nineties. Where will you guys be in 10 years time? Will people look back and make those same comments? Will they see that the legacy you left to young Australians was that you trained them, you skilled them up and you made them a highpaid, high-skilled, efficient work force able to deal with their place on a global scale? I do not think that is going to be the story, and the evidence is right here in this bill. I will end by saying a couple of things about the Springfield education park. In my view, this is by any measure probably the falmost significant consortium put together for an Australian technical college. I have looked at its proposal. It would be one of the strongest and most robust proposals, would present exceptional value for money for the government and would provide one of the best education and training facilities in a high-need area through the western corridor. We have the young people who are looking for the skills and work, we have the land, we have the industry and we have the cooperation-we have everything it takes. The application process should be simply based on merit. We hear Brendan Nelson talk about merit in education and proper testing and assessment. Minister, here is a chance for you to put it into practice. If you really based it on proper criteria and assessment, you would go out there and have a look at the Springfield education park in my electorate and you would see that it is probably one of the top facilities in Australia. But we are not going to get one, not because we do not have the best proposal; we are just not going to get one because the government is not interested in the western corridor. That is where the high needs are; that is not where it is interested. It is interested in keeping itself busy in National and Liberal Party seats. My message to the government is: have a good close look and a good cold hard think about what you are trying to achieve with this. You have already won the election, so move beyond that and start thinking of the Australian economy, start thinking of young people, start thinking of the skills crisis we have in this country and start doing something about it today.
